threats.title: Developer commits secret to GIT
threats.description: A developer commits AWS secrets to version control either accidentally or on purpose. An angry employee with read access to the repository finds the secrets and proceeds to use them to steal end-user data.
threats.mitigation:
Git secrets to help detect, flag and block merge requests/pull requests that contain secrets.
Secret management techniques such as Vaults should be used.
"Need to Know": ensure that production secrets are not shared with individuals who don't have a need to know.
"Least Privilege": users are given access to the minimum secrets/privileges required to perform their job. This may also include permitting and revoking privileges regularly, based on immediate requirements.

Using Vaults and Git secrets via GitHub: this prevents secrets from being accessible by humans after they've been saved in GitHub (they can still be accessed by the pipeline as required).

Educating the developers on the dangers of committing secrets in the code. 

Logging should be enabled so that secret usage can be tracked to the system (including who acquired and used the secrets).

Threat detections to detect anomalies in patterns of service operation.

Version control system should only be accessible on a corporate VPN.

threats.title: Develop laptop is lost or stolen
threats.description: The unencrypted hard drive can be used by an attacker to bypass password authentication, and commit access to all repositories/ssh access to systems that the developer had access to.
threats.mitigation:
All laptops should be encrypted.
Developers' access to repositories should be following the principles of least privilege.
Enterprise management software should be used for company computers.
Devices should be attached to the domain.
End point protection, such as Crowdstrike, should be running on all devices.

threats.title: Malicious package on public GitHub repo used in project
threats.description: A developer creates a benign looking and named, but yet malicious package and hosts it on a public GitHub repo. While working on a feature, the developer adds their malicious package into the project, backdooring the codebase.
threats.mitigation:
All merge requests are reviewed and approved by other engineers.
Administrative policies are created that mandates packages from approved sources are used.
Technical control tooling should be used in CI pipelines to identify non-company sanctioned repositories.
Threat detections to detect anomalies in patterns of service operation.

threats.title: Attacker employed by company and finds exploits
threats.description: A nation-state attacker proceeds to get one of their operatives employed with the company. After performing reconnaissance on the corporate network, they determine that the version control system has been operating with unpatched vulnerabilities. The attacker proceeds to compromise the version control server and implant malware which backdoors the company code releases
threats.mitigation:
Ensure corporate patch management policy exists that outlines SLA’s for patching of systems.
Automate vulnerability scanning of systems and software to identify unpatched vulnerabilities.
Ensure the company performs background checks on all new employees.
Ensure the principal of least privilege is followed and employees who don’t need access to systems are not provided access to systems.
Ensure the network is segregated so employees only have network access to the systems that are applicable to their job function.
Enable and use threat detection such as GuardDuty to detect anomolies in patterns of service operation.
Ensure version control system is only available on the corporate VPN.
Ensure security groups / firewalls are configured to only allow necessary network access.
Ensure company hardening standards exist which outline procedures for hardening systems.
Ensure the version control system is hardened in alignment with corporate standards including things such as:
Removing all un-necessary services
Disabling root login
Disabling password login
Using a “golden image”
Using minimal containers if running a containerized environment

Implement a SIEM and forward events, syslog, etc.

threats.title: Open source dependency used in application is attacked for bitcoin mining
threats.description: An popular opensource dependency used by the application gets compromised by an attacker. The attacker implants bitcoin mining software into the dependency so that consuming applications will mine bitcoin for the attacker
threats.mitigation:
Ensure automated dependency analysis is being performed on application dependencies to detect dependencies known to have been compromised.
Ensure lock files are being used so that builds repeatedly use the same version of a dependency until it is explicitly upgraded.
Enable and use threat detection such as GuardDuty to detect anomolies in patterns of service operation.
Create administrative policy that mandates packages must only come from company approved sources.
Build and integrate tooling into CI pipelines as a technical control that reviews package files and identifies non-company sanctioned repositories; enforcing company policy.
Subscribe the engineering team to security disclosure distro lists so that they may be alerted when supply chain attacks are discovered.

threats.title: Inadequate Container Registry Permissions Lead to Backdoored Image Deployment
threats.description: Developers are given access to the container registry so that they may publish POC / testing images or pull production images for debugging purposes. Container registry permissions are not well segmented and allow a developer to push images to the same registry that production images are pulled from. A developer proceeds to publish a backdoored image directly to the repository and tags as latest, knowing that it will get picked up as part of the next deploy.
threats.mitigation:
Ensure logging is configured for the container registry so that all image pushes and pulls are captured.
Do not use the same container registry for developer testing / POC that is used for production image storage.
Restrict publish access to the production container registry to only the CI/CD system.
Enable and use threat detection such as GuardDuty to detect anomolies in patterns of service operation.
Implement image signing that will only allow the deployment of images that have been properly signed.
Review Google’s Binary Autnorization for Borg and consider adopting some of their controls.
